element.name: DESCRIPTION
element.text: The extension Analytical Hierarchy Process(AHP) (Saaty, 1977) is used to calculate relative weights in order to combine several factors. This algorithm uses the input layers and a table with a number of factors (equal to the number of layers), comparing their comparative weights to calculate a new layer as a linear combination of the input layers.

element.name: PAIRWISE
element.text: A table determining the relevance of each factor contained in the input layers by comparing them one by one. The table should have n rows and n columns, n being the number of factors (this is, of layers) to which comparative values will be assigned. It is recommended that these values are established between 1 and 9 according on the following rules: * 1 = The same importance * 3 = Moderate predominance of one value over another * 5 = Strong predominance * 7 = Very Strong Predominance * 9 = Extreme Predominance * 2, 4, 6, 8 = Intermediate Values

image.description: Example of matrix table for three layers

element.name: RESULT
element.text: Result of the linear combination of the input layers based on the weights established by the analytical hierarchy process.
